abstract.p: Letter from Caroline Fredrickson, director of American Civil Liberties Union's Washington legislative office, holds that voter ID laws restrict access to polls and have disproportionate impact on minority voters (Feb 21 article)

block.p: ''Lower Voter Turnout Is Seen in States That Require ID'' (news article, Feb. 21) demonstrates once again what opponents of voter ID laws have said all along: they restrict access to the polls and have a disproportionate impact on minority voters.

''Lower Voter Turnout Is Seen in States That Require ID'' (news article, Feb. 21) demonstrates once again what opponents of voter ID laws have said all along: they restrict access to the polls and have a disproportionate impact on minority voters.

There are many voters who don't have a photo ID, and requiring them to buy one is equivalent to a poll tax. Voter IDs cost money; even if the IDs themselves are free, the documents required to get them are not.

If we are truly committed to improving the electoral system, there are much bigger -- and more common -- voting problems to address, like inaccurate registration rolls, malfunctioning voting machines and untrained poll workers.
Instead of putting hurdles in the way of voters, states should be working to remove them and to ensure that every eligible voter is allowed to vote and that every vote counts.
Caroline Fredrickson Director, A.C.L.U. Washington Legislative Office Washington, Feb. 22, 2007
